<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
SOCIAL MEDIA
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/11/29/jack-dorsey-steps-down-as-twitter-ceo-for-big-defi-dreams?mid={{md5(profile.email)}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Jack Hits the Road
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/11/29/jack-dorsey-steps-down-as-twitter-ceo-for-big-defi-dreams?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="Jack Dorsey animorphing invisible" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/5c16866719adaf0b7d2d70982dda28d2b118c624-1500x1000.jpg?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em><em>Photo Illustration: Mick McDougall; Getty Images/Joe Raedle</em></em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">After eight years of watching brands bully random people on Twitter, Jack Dorsey <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2021/11/29/twitter-ceo-jack-dorsey-is-expected-to-step-down-sources-say.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">said</a> he was stepping down as the company’s CEO yesterday. He’s handed the keys to the birdcage to Parag Agrawal, Twitter’s current CTO.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">300-character background:</strong> Dorsey cofounded Twitter in 2006, and served as the hot-take site’s first CEO until he was pushed to chairman in 2008. Since he returned to the corner office in 2015, Twitter became profitable and established itself as the world’s digital watercooler for culture and politics. But a lack of product innovation and (some argue) mismanagement means it’s still sitting at the social media kids table.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px"><li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Twitter’s stock climbed 67% during Dorsey’s most recent tenure, compared to Meta’s (formerly Facebook) 260%. And Twitter only snagged $3.7 billion in revenue last year, while Meta raked in almost $86 billion.</span></li></ul>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">You can’t fit a Twitter peg into a Square hole</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">In a <a href="https://twitter.com/jack/status/1465347002426867720?s=20" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">letter to staff</a>, Dorsey said he was leaving in part because he believes the company is ready to move on from its founders. But it’s worth noting that Dorsey is staying on as CEO of another company he cofounded: the payments giant Square. He’d been double-dipping as CEO of both Square and Twitter since 2015.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Decentralize Dorsey.</strong> The tech mogul has expressed his undying love for bitcoin numerous times, saying at one point it could bring about world peace. Some analysts speculate that Dorsey’s departure is mostly about <a href="https://qz.com/2095860/why-jack-dorsey-chose-square-over-twitter/?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">freeing up time</a> for making big crypto moves at Square.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px"><li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Square began offering bitcoin trading through Cash App in 2018, created an independent team for bitcoin open-source work in 2019, and announced it would launch a whole new business to build decentralized finance (DeFi) apps for bitcoin in July.</span></li></ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Crypto might also be central to Twitter’s roadmap. </strong>Agrawal, a machine-learning and AI expert, has been leading the company’s Bluesky project that aims to create a “decentralized standard” for social media. And apparently he’s only ever had positive airport experiences, tweeting only 10 times this year.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">+ Fun fact: </strong>Argawal joins the growing ranks of powerful US tech executives of Indian descent. Google, Microsoft, Adobe, IBM, Palo Alto Networks, and now Twitter are all run by people who grew up in India.<em>—MM</em></p>
</div>

<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
COVID
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/11/29/omicron-update?mid={{md5(profile.email)}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Omicron Update
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/11/29/omicron-update?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="A collage of images portraying the Omicron variant" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/1ca66b17a4a0963e4773f62b0bd866295b0cb225-1500x1000.jpg?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Francis Scialabba</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">As scientists work to collect more information about the new, highly mutated variant of Covid-19 called Omicron, world leaders are stressing patience, feuding over travel bans, and pushing boosters. Here’s the latest.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Biden tried to soothe Americans’ nerves: </strong>The president called Omicron a “cause for concern, not a cause for panic.” He <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2021/11/29/biden-says-he-doesnt-expect-more-travel-restrictions-or-lockdowns-as-omicron-covid-variant-spreads.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">doesn’t anticipate</a> additional travel restrictions or lockdowns on account of Omicron, which gave a boost to airline stocks.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Speaking of travel bans: </strong>They’re extremely contentious.<strong style="color:#000"> </strong>The UN’s secretary-general <a href="https://www.jpost.com/health-and-wellness/coronavirus/un-condemns-countries-for-placing-travel-restrictions-against-africa-687324?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">called out</a> the many countries who’ve banned travel from southern Africa, where the new strain was first detected, saying that region “should not be penalized for identifying and sharing crucial science...with the world.” Japan, Morocco, and Israel have closed their borders to all outside travelers.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Therapeutics: </strong>Companies working on treatments that combat Covid-19 said they believed their drugs <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2021/11/29/pfizer-ceo-confident-covid-treatment-pill-effective-against-omicron-variant.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">would be effective</a> against Omicron. Pfizer’s CEO said his company’s antiviral pill was designed with mutations in mind, so he has a “very high level of confidence” it will work.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Everything else:</strong></p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>The UK is speeding up its booster rollout in light of Omicron, opening up third shots to all adults.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>New York City is strongly recommending all people, regardless of vaccination status, wear masks indoors at all times.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">—<em>NF</em></p>
</div>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
LABOR
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/11/29/amazon-warehouse-workers-in-alabama-will-get-a-second-chance-at-unionizing?mid={{md5(profile.email)}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Call It the Amazon Echo
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The National Labor Relations Board (NLRB) had a Cyber Monday blowout of its own: free second chances for Amazon workers attempting to unionize.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Workers at an Amazon facility in Bessemer, AL, are getting a <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2021/11/29/amazon-warehouse-union-revote/?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">second union vote</a> after the NLRB found that the retail giant improperly interfered with the first election back in March. That vote resulted in a more than 2-to-1 defeat for the ​​Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union (RWDSU)—the labor union behind the Bessemer organizing drive.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Why the second chance? </strong>The union alleged that during the first election, Amazon pressured workers to cast their votes in a mailbox on company property, in view of security cameras. This could have given workers the impression that Amazon would have a role in counting ballots and may have intimidated them into voting no, the NLRB found.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">According to an NLRB official, employees also could have inferred that Amazon was tracking their vote by maintaining a list of who took “vote no” pins, which Amazon handed out leading up to the election.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out:</strong> With Amazon’s high employee turnover rate, the company’s staunch opposition to unionization, and a wage that goes further in Bessemer than in larger cities, the union still faces a tough battle in Alabama. The second vote has not been given a date.—<em>MK</em></p>
</div>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
TOGETHER WITH THE MOTLEY FOOL
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="#" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Their Word Is as Good as Picks and Shovels
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>

<a href="https://www.fool.com/ext-content/why-this-one-stock-set-to-make-money-on-bitcoin-at/?utm_source=morningbrew&utm_medium=contentmarketing&utm_campaign=bb-bitcoinboom&aid=9528&paid=9528&waid=9528&source=esamnbwdg0500026&psource=esamnbwdg0500026&wsource=esamnbwdg0500026&testId=a-sa-btc-boom-2&cellId=0&campaign=sa-bitcoin-boom%20" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="The Motley Fool" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://media2.morningbrew.com/uploads/placement/images/2184/1636570862-Cryptocurrency-4.jpg">
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em></em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Yes, we know that’s not the saying. But we’re trying to make a point here. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">That point is: Crypto right now is, shall we say, not unlike a gold rush. And that means there could be just as much opportunity in the tools being used as there could be in the shiny rocks. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Crypto tokens are like shiny rocks indeed, but a great crypto investment strategy has potential to make investors $$$ regardless of whether a given token is <img src="https://emojipedia-us.s3.dualstack.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/thumbs/120/apple/237/chart-with-upwards-trend_1f4c8.png" width="18" style="max-width:18px" alt="">-ing or not on a given day. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><a href="https://www.fool.com/ext-content/why-this-one-stock-set-to-make-money-on-bitcoin-at/?utm_source=morningbrew&utm_medium=contentmarketing&utm_campaign=bb-bitcoinboom&aid=9528&paid=9528&waid=9528&source=esamnbwdg0500026&psource=esamnbwdg0500026&wsource=esamnbwdg0500026&testId=a-sa-btc-boom-2&cellId=0&campaign=sa-bitcoin-boom" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">The Motley Fool</a> found a company that might be perfectly poised as a long-term shovel—a sturdy metal one with a nice leather handle, if you will—for the broader crypto market. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">And these folks put their decentralized currencies where their mouths are: <a href="https://www.fool.com/ext-content/why-this-one-stock-set-to-make-money-on-bitcoin-at/?utm_source=morningbrew&utm_medium=contentmarketing&utm_campaign=bb-bitcoinboom&aid=9528&paid=9528&waid=9528&source=esamnbwdg0500026&psource=esamnbwdg0500026&wsource=esamnbwdg0500026&testId=a-sa-btc-boom-2&cellId=0&campaign=sa-bitcoin-boom" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">The Motley Fool</a> has invested $5 million in bitcoin, so you know they’re putting their crypto chips on the table with their members. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><a href="https://www.fool.com/ext-content/why-this-one-stock-set-to-make-money-on-bitcoin-at/?utm_source=morningbrew&utm_medium=contentmarketing&utm_campaign=bb-bitcoinboom&aid=9528&paid=9528&waid=9528&source=esamnbwdg0500026&psource=esamnbwdg0500026&wsource=esamnbwdg0500026&testId=a-sa-btc-boom-2&cellId=0&campaign=sa-bitcoin-boom" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Learn more about investing in crypto for the long term here</a>. </p>
</td>

<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
GRAB BAG
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/11/29/key-performance-indicators-november-30?mid={{md5(profile.email)}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Key Performance Indicators
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Stat: </strong>On Giving Tuesday, here are some <a href="https://www.nptrust.org/philanthropic-resources/charitable-giving-statistics/?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">figures</a> on the state of philanthropy in the US…</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Americans gave $471.44 billion in 2020, which accounted for 2.3% of GDP.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>More charitable dollars went to religion (28%) than anywhere else.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Jeff Bezos was the top donor in 2020, giving $10.2 billion, followed by MacKenzie Scott ($5.7 billion) and Michael Bloomberg ($1.6 billion).</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Quote: </strong>“This was a word that was extremely high in our data every single day in 2021.”</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Merriam-Webster’s Editor at Large Peter Sokolowski explained why the company chose “<a href="https://apnews.com/article/merriam-webster-word-of-year-vaccine-89de731624901bc53f4febdbc5925f80?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">vaccine</a>” as its 2021 word of the year. Lookups for the word surged 601% over 2020, when “pandemic” was Merriam-Webster’s word of the year.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Read: </strong>The secretive prisons that keep migrants out of Europe. (<a href="https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2021/12/06/the-secretive-libyan-prisons-that-keep-migrants-out-of-europe?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">The New Yorker</a>)</p>
</div>

<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
ENTERTAINMENT
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/11/29/an-episode-of-the-simpsons-mocking-chinese-censorship-has-been-censored-in-hong-kong?mid={{md5(profile.email)}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Springfield <del>Un</del>censored
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/11/29/an-episode-of-the-simpsons-mocking-chinese-censorship-has-been-censored-in-hong-kong?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt='A cartoon sign from the Simpsons reading "Tienanmen Square: Oh this site, in 1989, nothing happened."' style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/99c1e971f3e1e34e656975d2809e34001fc6bb8c-646x364.png?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>FOX</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Does this count as another <em>Simpsons</em> prediction? An episode of <em>The Simpsons</em> featuring jokes about Chinese censorship <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/11/29/world/asia/simpsons-hk.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">is absent</a> from the recently launched Disney+ in Hong Kong.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Hong Kong Disney+ subscribers trying to watch <em>The Simpsons</em> will notice that episode 12 of season 16 isn’t in the show archive. The missing episode, titled “Goo Goo Gai Pan,” centers around a Simpson family visit to China where Homer describes Mao Zedong as looking “like a little angel that killed 50 million people.” The family also passes a sign in Tiananmen Square (where several hundred protestors were killed by Chinese soldiers and police in 1989) that reads, “On this site, in 1989, nothing happened.”</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">It’s unclear whether Disney preemptively censored the episode or if the company was asked to do so by government officials. A recent film censorship law grants the Hong Kong government the ability to censor movies on national security grounds—but it doesn’t apply to streaming services, according to a government statement.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out: </strong>Hong Kong has been cracking down on art that references Tiananmen Square. The University of Hong Kong is removing a 24-year-old <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/asia_pacific/hongkong-pillar-shame-tiananmen/2021/10/13/2a897036-2b0a-11ec-b17d-985c186de338_story.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">memorial statue</a>, and a photograph by exiled Chinese artist Ai Weiwei has been scrapped from the online archive of Hong Kong’s new art museum, M+.—<em>MK</em></p>
</div>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

GAMES
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="#" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
The Puzzle Section
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Brew Mini: </strong>Thank you, <em>Harry Potter, </em>for helping us solve the clue “Make out, in Britspeak.” <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/11/29/brew-mini?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Play the full puzzle here</a>.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">The Quitting Diaries</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">In light of Jack Dorsey stepping down from Twitter, we pored through famous resignation letters in history. For this quiz, we’ll give you an excerpt from a notable figure’s resignation letter; you have to name the person.</p>
<ol>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>“I have always said if there ever came a day when I could no longer meet my duties and expectations as Apple’s CEO, I would be the first to let you know. Unfortunately, that day has come.”</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>“Dear Mr. Secretary: I hereby resign the Office of President of the United States.”</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>“After having repeatedly examined my conscience before God, I have come to the certainty that my strengths, due to an advanced age, are no longer suited to an adequate exercise of the Petrine ministry.”</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>“Keep inventing, and don't despair when at first the idea looks crazy. Remember to wander. Let curiosity be your compass. It remains Day 1.”</span></li>
</ol>
</div>
</td>
</tr>

</th>
</tr>
</table>

<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">To enter the raffle, all you need to do is slam that share button below and get a friend signed up to the Brew before midnight (ET) tonight. years of watching brands bully random people on Twitter, Jack Dorsey \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2021/11/29/twitter-ceo-jack-dorsey-is-expected-to-step-down-sources-say.html?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003esaid\u003c/a\u003e he was stepping down as the company’s CEO yesterday. He’s handed the keys to the birdcage to Parag Agrawal, Twitter’s current CTO.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e300-character background:\u003c/strong\u003e Dorsey cofounded Twitter in 2006, and served as the hot-take site’s first CEO until he was pushed to chairman in 2008. Since he returned to the corner office in 2015, Twitter became profitable and established itself as the world’s digital watercooler for culture and politics. But a lack of product innovation and (some argue) mismanagement means it’s still sitting at the social media kids table.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eTwitter’s stock climbed 67% during Dorsey’s most recent tenure, compared to Meta’s (formerly Facebook) 260%. And Twitter only snagged $3.7 billion in revenue last year, while Meta raked in almost $86 billion.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eYou can’t fit a Twitter peg into a Square hole\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIn a \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/jack/status/1465347002426867720?s=20\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eletter to staff\u003c/a\u003e, Dorsey said he was leaving in part because he believes the company is ready to move on from its founders. But it’s worth noting that Dorsey is staying on as CEO of another company he cofounded: the payments giant Square. He’d been double-dipping as CEO of both Square and Twitter since 2015.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eDecentralize Dorsey.\u003c/strong\u003e The tech mogul has expressed his undying love for bitcoin numerous times, saying at one point it could bring about world peace. Some analysts speculate that Dorsey’s departure is mostly about \u003ca href=\"https://qz.com/2095860/why-jack-dorsey-chose-square-over-twitter/?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003efreeing up time\u003c/a\u003e for making big crypto moves at Square.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eSquare began offering bitcoin trading through Cash App in 2018, created an independent team for bitcoin open-source work in 2019, and announced it would launch a whole new business to build decentralized finance (DeFi) apps for bitcoin in July.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eCrypto might also be central to Twitter’s roadmap. \u003c/strong\u003eAgrawal, a machine-learning and AI expert, has been leading the company’s Bluesky project that aims to create a “decentralized standard” for social media. And apparently he’s only ever had positive airport experiences, tweeting only 10 times this year.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e+ Fun fact: \u003c/strong\u003eArgawal joins the growing ranks of powerful US tech executives of Indian descent. Google, Microsoft, Adobe, IBM, Palo Alto Networks, and now Twitter are all run by people who grew up in India.\u003cem\u003e—MM\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAs scientists work to collect more information about the new, highly mutated variant of Covid-19 called Omicron, world leaders are stressing patience, feuding over travel bans, and pushing boosters. Here’s the latest.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBiden tried to soothe Americans’ nerves: \u003c/strong\u003eThe president called Omicron a “cause for concern, not a cause for panic.” He \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2021/11/29/biden-says-he-doesnt-expect-more-travel-restrictions-or-lockdowns-as-omicron-covid-variant-spreads.html?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003edoesn’t anticipate\u003c/a\u003e additional travel restrictions or lockdowns on account of Omicron, which gave a boost to airline stocks.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eSpeaking of travel bans: \u003c/strong\u003eThey’re extremely contentious.\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e \u003c/strong\u003eThe UN’s secretary-general \u003ca href=\"https://www.jpost.com/health-and-wellness/coronavirus/un-condemns-countries-for-placing-travel-restrictions-against-africa-687324?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ecalled out\u003c/a\u003e the many countries who’ve banned travel from southern Africa, where the new strain was first detected, saying that region “should not be penalized for identifying and sharing crucial science...with the world.” Japan, Morocco, and Israel have closed their borders to all outside travelers.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eTherapeutics: \u003c/strong\u003eCompanies working on treatments that combat Covid-19 said they believed their drugs \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2021/11/29/pfizer-ceo-confident-covid-treatment-pill-effective-against-omicron-variant.html?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ewould be effective\u003c/a\u003e against Omicron. Pfizer’s CEO said his company’s antiviral pill was designed with mutations in mind, so he has a “very high level of confidence” it will work.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eEverything else:\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe UK is speeding up its booster rollout in light of Omicron, opening up third shots to all adults.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eNew York City is strongly recommending all people, regardless of vaccination status, wear masks indoors at all times.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;\"\u003e\n\u003cfont color=\"#000000\"\u003e\nCall It the Amazon Echo\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe National Labor Relations Board (NLRB) had a Cyber Monday blowout of its own: free second chances for Amazon workers attempting to unionize.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWorkers at an Amazon facility in Bessemer, AL, are getting a \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2021/11/29/amazon-warehouse-union-revote/?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003esecond union vote\u003c/a\u003e after the NLRB found that the retail giant improperly interfered with the first election back in March. That vote resulted in a more than 2-to-1 defeat for the ​​Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union (RWDSU)—the labor union behind the Bessemer organizing drive.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eWhy the second chance? \u003c/strong\u003eThe union alleged that during the first election, Amazon pressured workers to cast their votes in a mailbox on company property, in view of security cameras. This could have given workers the impression that Amazon would have a role in counting ballots and may have intimidated them into voting no, the NLRB found.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAccording to an NLRB official, employees also could have inferred that Amazon was tracking their vote by maintaining a list of who took “vote no” pins, which Amazon handed out leading up to the election.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom out:\u003c/strong\u003e With Amazon’s high employee turnover rate, the company’s staunch opposition to unionization, and a wage that goes further in Bessemer than in larger cities, the union still faces a tough battle in Alabama. The second vote has not been given a date.—\u003cem\u003eMK\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eDoes this count as another \u003cem\u003eSimpsons\u003c/em\u003e prediction? An episode of \u003cem\u003eThe Simpsons\u003c/em\u003e featuring jokes about Chinese censorship \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2021/11/29/world/asia/simpsons-hk.html?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eis absent\u003c/a\u003e from the recently launched Disney+ in Hong Kong.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eHong Kong Disney+ subscribers trying to watch \u003cem\u003eThe Simpsons\u003c/em\u003e will notice that episode 12 of season 16 isn’t in the show archive. The missing episode, titled “Goo Goo Gai Pan,” centers around a Simpson family visit to China where Homer describes Mao Zedong as looking “like a little angel that killed 50 million people.” The family also passes a sign in Tiananmen Square (where several hundred protestors were killed by Chinese soldiers and police in 1989) that reads, “On this site, in 1989, nothing happened.”\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIt’s unclear whether Disney preemptively censored the episode or if the company was asked to do so by government officials. A recent film censorship law grants the Hong Kong government the ability to censor movies on national security grounds—but it doesn’t apply to streaming services, according to a government statement.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom out: \u003c/strong\u003eHong Kong has been cracking down on art that references Tiananmen Square. The University of Hong Kong is removing a 24-year-old \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/asia_pacific/hongkong-pillar-shame-tiananmen/2021/10/13/2a897036-2b0a-11ec-b17d-985c186de338_story.html?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ememorial statue\u003c/a\u003e, and a photograph by exiled Chinese artist Ai Weiwei has been scrapped from the online archive of Hong Kong’s new art museum, M+.—\u003cem\u003eMK\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\"
